title: Prototype pollution in dot-prop

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information:
I would like to report a parameter pollution in dot-prop
It allows an attacker to modify the prototype of a base object which can vary in severity depending on the implementation (DoS, access to sensitive data, RCE).

# Module

**module name:** dot-prop
**version:** 5.1.1
**npm page:** https://www.npmjs.com/package/dot-prop

## Module Description

Get, set, or delete a property from a nested object using a dot path

## Module Stats

weekly downloads:
8,627,892

# Vulnerability

## Vulnerability Description

See previous description

## Steps To Reproduce:

```
var dotProp = require("dot-prop")
const object = {};
console.log("Before " + object.b); //Undefined
dotProp.set(object, '__proto__.b', true);
console.log("After " + {}.b); //true
```

# Wrap up

> Select Y or N for the following statements:

- I contacted the maintainer to let them know: N
- I opened an issue in the related repository: N

## Impact

Can result in: dos, access to restricted data, rce (depends on implementation)

activities.message:
Hi @aaron_costello,

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@nochnoidozor

activities.message:
Hello @aaron_costello,

Thank you for your submission! We were able to validate your report, and have submitted it to the appropriate remediation team for review. They will let us know the final ruling on this report, and when/if a fix will be implemented. Please note that the status and severity are subject to change.

Regards,
@nochnoidozor

activities.message: Did you actually run the code snippet you have provided? Because `console.log("After " + {}.b);` results in `undefined`, not `true` with `dot-prop@5.1.1`.
activities.markdown_message: Did you actually run the code snippet you have provided? Because console.log("After " + {}.b); results in undefined, not true with dot-prop@5.1.1.

activities.message:
I confirmed that @sindresorhus is right and that version 5.1.1 is not affected (the issue is fixed in this commit: https://github.com/sindresorhus/dot-prop/commit/3039c8c07f6fdaa8b595ec869ae0895686a7a0f2).

@aaron_costello @nochnoidozor It looks like 5.1.0 and earlier are affected. Can you confirm this?
activities.markdown_message:
I confirmed that @sindresorhus is right and that version 5.1.1 is not affected (the issue is fixed in this commit: https://github.com/sindresorhus/dot-prop/commit/3039c8c07f6fdaa8b595ec869ae0895686a7a0f2).

@aaron_costello @nochnoidozor It looks like 5.1.0 and earlier are affected. Can you confirm this?

@sindresorhus ,

Yes, of course the code snippet was tested.

If you notice the commit that @marcinhoppe posted, the date of the commit (fix) is Oct 23rd. This report however, was reported earlier (October 22nd) when the issue was in existence. This is solidified by the HackerOne triage team, since they validated that the issue was reproducible in 5.1.1 (Issue was marked as 'Triaged - We were able to validate your report', as opposed to 'N/A - Not reproducible').

activities.message:
@nochnoidozor can you clarify which version was used in the reproduction? The report seems to indicate that 5.1.1 was tested and now we verified it is not affected.

@sindresorhus I still there is still value in disclosing this vulnerability in 5.1.0 and earlier to prompt dot-prop users to upgrade. Are you OK with public disclosure? I don't think it would require any further action on your part.
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message:
@marcinhoppe ,

Version 5.1.1 was tested on my end, the fix was made after the vulnerability was reported here (This is just a matter of comparing the dates). Nonetheless, I agree with closing as resolved since this is now fixed and to assist in the securing of user's whom may not have upgraded to the latest version (<5.1.1).
